title: What is Law?
textSnippet: Law as an authoritative system In the United States, law is a body of enforceable commands issued or recognized by legitimate public institutions. Those commands take written form—such as a statute, regulation, or con…

title: Sources of Law
textSnippet: Constitutional supremacy The Constitution is the supreme law of the land. Article VI, the Supremacy Clause, binds judges in every state to follow federal law whenever it conflicts with a state enactment. Constitutiona…

title: Precedent and Hierarchy
textSnippet: Binding versus persuasive authority Binding precedent compels a court to follow a rule announced by a higher tribunal in the same jurisdiction. For example, a District Court must apply holdings from its Court of Appea…

title: Supreme Court Practice Overview
textSnippet: Jurisdiction and docket control The Supreme Court exercises appellate jurisdiction over cases arising from federal courts and state courts that decide federal questions. Most cases arrive by petition for a writ of cer…

title: adversary system
textSnippet: Structure of litigation in which opposing parties present evidence and arguments before a neutral decision maker.

title: administrative law
textSnippet: Body of law governing the creation, operation, and review of actions by administrative agencies.

title: appellate review
textSnippet: Examination of a lower tribunal's decision by a higher court for legal error.

title: Article III
textSnippet: Constitutional article establishing the federal judicial branch and defining the limits of federal judicial power.

title: brief
textSnippet: Written submission that explains a party's legal and factual arguments to a court.

title: burden of proof
textSnippet: Obligation of a party to prove a fact or persuade the fact finder of a claim's validity.

title: case law
textSnippet: Judicial decisions that interpret statutes, regulations, and constitutional provisions.

title: certiorari
textSnippet: Discretionary order by which the Supreme Court agrees to review a lower court's judgment.

title: civil procedure
textSnippet: Rules and statutes that govern the process of civil litigation from filing to judgment.

title: common law
textSnippet: Judge-made law developed through precedent rather than enacted legislation.

title: complaint
textSnippet: Initial pleading in a civil action that states the plaintiff's claims and requests relief.

title: Constitution
textSnippet: Foundational legal charter establishing government structure and protecting individual rights.

title: deference
textSnippet: Judicial respect for the decisions or interpretations of another branch or decision maker.

title: discovery
textSnippet: Pretrial process for obtaining evidence from other parties or nonparties.

title: District Court
textSnippet: General federal trial court with original jurisdiction over civil and criminal matters.

title: due process
textSnippet: Constitutional requirement that government procedures be fair and follow established rules.

title: en banc
textSnippet: Session in which a full appellate court, rather than a panel, hears and decides a case.

title: equitable relief
textSnippet: Nonmonetary remedy such as injunction, declaratory judgment, or specific performance.

title: evidence
textSnippet: Testimony, documents, or tangible objects presented to prove or disprove facts at issue.

title: federal question
textSnippet: Claim arising under the Constitution, laws, or treaties of the United States.

title: federalism
textSnippet: Constitutional division of authority between the federal government and the states.

title: final judgment rule
textSnippet: Doctrine limiting appellate review to decisions that resolve all claims for all parties.

title: case flow
textSnippet: Overall progression of a matter from investigation through final resolution.

title: holding
textSnippet: Legal principle necessary to resolve the dispute before the court.

title: injunction
textSnippet: Court order directing a party to do or refrain from doing a specific act.

title: jurisdiction
textSnippet: Power of a court to hear and decide a case.

title: legislative history
textSnippet: Materials generated during enactment of a statute that may inform interpretation.

title: mens rea
textSnippet: Mental state required as an element of a crime, such as intent or knowledge.

title: notice
textSnippet: Information that informs a person of legal proceedings or obligations affecting them.

title: original jurisdiction
textSnippet: Authority of a court to hear a case in the first instance.

title: personal jurisdiction
textSnippet: Court's power to render a judgment affecting a particular defendant's rights or obligations.

title: plea bargain
textSnippet: Agreement in which a criminal defendant pleads guilty in exchange for concessions.

title: precedent
textSnippet: Prior judicial decision that guides the outcome of later cases involving similar facts or law.

title: probable cause
textSnippet: Reasonable ground to believe that a crime has been committed and that the suspect committed it.

title: procedural due process
textSnippet: Requirement that the government follow fair procedures before depriving a person of life, liberty, or property.

title: remand
textSnippet: Order by an appellate court sending a case back to a lower court for further proceedings.

title: remedies
textSnippet: Legal or equitable relief provided to address a violation of rights.

title: rule of law
textSnippet: Principle that government officials and citizens are bound by and accountable to the law.

title: service of process
textSnippet: Formal delivery of legal documents to notify a party of proceedings.

title: stare decisis
textSnippet: Doctrine requiring courts to follow controlling precedent absent a compelling reason to depart.

title: statute
textSnippet: Law enacted by a legislature and codified in the United States Code or state code.

title: subject-matter jurisdiction
textSnippet: Authority of a court to hear cases of a particular type or category.

title: Supreme Court
textSnippet: Highest court in the United States with final authority over federal law and the Constitution.

title: suppression
textSnippet: Exclusion of evidence obtained in violation of constitutional or statutory rights.

title: venue
textSnippet: Proper geographic location for a court to hear a case.

title: voir dire
textSnippet: Process of questioning prospective jurors to assess qualifications and impartiality.

title: writ
textSnippet: Formal written order issued by a court directing a specific action.
